titleStmt.title: To his very good friend, Master Henry Cockeram, on his Vo∣cabulary.

publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

analytic.title: To his very good friend, Master Henry Cockeram, on his Vo∣cabulary.

monogr.title: The English dictionarie: or, An interpreter of hard English vvords : Enabling as well ladies and gentlewomen, young schollers, clarkes, merchants, as also strangers of any nation, to the vnderstanding of the more difficult authors already printed in our language, and the more speedy attaining of an elegant perfection of the English tongue, both in reading, speaking and writing. Being a collection of the choisest words contained in the Table alphabeticall and English expositor, and of some thousands of words neuer published by any heretofore. By H.C. Gent
monogr.author: Cockeram, Henry

keywords.term: Dictionaries, vocabularies, phrase books, instruction in foreign languages

div.head: To his very good friend, Master Henry Cockeram, on his Vocabulary.

lg.l: He whose selfe loue, or too ambitious spirit,
Enuies or carpes at this thy Muses action,
Nere let him liue, or of a Muse once merit
Regard or fame, but die in his detraction,
Ere he once taste of Hellicons delight.
Could I, oh could I quintessence my skill,
Knowledge with learning should instruct my quill
Effectually to praise thy Muses guise,
Among some captious, yet wise seeming masters,
Made by her curious eye, their owne distasters.

closer.signed: Nicholas Smith, Eques Auratus Encomiastes Posthumus.
